We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible case of polymyalgia rheumatica, which is associated with elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Therefore, the best next step in management would be to perform an ESR test. Lumbar puncture is unlikely to be helpful in this case as the patient is presenting with muscular symptoms rather than neurological symptoms. Electromyography (EMG) is used to diagnose muscle and nerve diseases and may be helpful in confirming the diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica, but it is not a first-line investigation. Antinuclear antibody testing is used to diagnose autoimmune diseases but is less likely to be relevant in this case as the patient's symptoms suggest a possible inflammatory condition rather than an autoimmune condition.

We refer to the UpToDate article on polymyalgia rheumatica for help. The patient's symptoms, including muscle pain and stiffness worse in the morning, suggest polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). Laboratory tests, including erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP), are commonly elevated in patients with PMR. Therefore, the best next step in management is to obtain an ESR to evaluate for PMR. Lumbar puncture, electromyography, and antinuclear antibody are not necessary for the evaluation and management of PMR.
